channel.title: 317 Server: (server.java) - "Timer"/declaring classes
channel.description:
Hello.
Before I go on to my questions/problems, I want you to bear in mind that this is my [b]very first topic[/b]! It's also about a [b]317 server[/b].
Answers I am looking for:
[b]1: Cycle timer[/b] [b]2: Defineing classes(?)[/b]
[b]Cycle timer:[/b] As I am browsing my [b]server/source's[/b] "server.java"-file, some of the very first commands below all the imports that I can't understand are about some sort of timeing...? I have been taking a "peek under the hood" of some other servers, and some of them are using "Bluurr's sexy timer" (or something like that). If I'm not [i]completely[/i] wrong, it has to do with determing how long the client listener's threads are going to "sleep", I take it? What I want to know here is why these timers are here, and why I can't simply delete them...
[b]Defineing classes(?):[/b] [i]This may be more of a question for Java than RSPS-related, but here I go[/i]: Also in the [b]server/source's[/b] "server.java"-file, there are some other commands that catches my eyes. Let me take an example... "[b]GraphicsHandler = new GraphicsHandler();[/b]". Yet again, if I'm not wrong, it defines ([i]in this case[/i]) the "GraphicsHandler.java"-file to "server.java". But I am used to define classes in a little bit different way, like this: "[b]GraphicsHandler <nickname> = new GraphicsHandler();[/b]". You then have to call the class by it's "nickname" when ever you are refering to it.
That's it. [b]I do NOT claim to be a professor in english[/b]. [b]I do NOT claim to be a professor in Java[/b]. [b]I do NOT claim to be the most experienced RS/RSPS player/coder among us all[/b]...
Looking forward for feedback.

item.description:
@Ole_Kristian wrote:

Thank you all!
I appreciate the feedback!

item.title: 317 Server: (server.java) - "Timer"/declaring classes
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

Event/Task systems should still be tick based. Runescape has confirmed that. but yea everything ^^ said is right

Read full topic

item.title: 317 Server: (server.java) - "Timer"/declaring classes
item.dc:creator: @Christmas_tree Christmas_tree
item.description:
@Christmas_tree wrote:

Chill out on the bolding hahaha

Ok, the usual RS cycle time is 600ms. Every 600ms the server and players are updated. However if you want to perform actions out-of-time (like you want to make a player do an emote once every 3000ms) we can use an event.

Yeah you should probably go read up on some java docs and begin to learn programming for yourself before approaching RSPS. Gl buddy

Read full topic

item.title: 317 Server: (server.java) - "Timer"/declaring classes
item.dc:creator: @PvPXile PvPXile
item.description:
@PvPXile wrote:

I believe bluurs timer is just his version of cycles, events etc, and it depends what they are used for to whether you can delete them.

GraphicsHandler = new GraphicsHandler(); is used to define the class to server.java, there is no need to nickname it.

Read full topic

item.title: 317 Server: (server.java) - "Timer"/declaring classes
item.dc:creator: @Ole_Kristian Ole Kristian
item.description:
@Ole_Kristian wrote:

Hello.

Before I go on to my questions/problems, I want you to bear in mind that this is my very first topic!
It’s also about a 317 server.

Answers I am looking for:

1: Cycle timer
2: Defineing classes(?)

Cycle timer:
As I am browsing my server/source’s “server.java”-file, some of the very first commands below all
the imports that I can’t understand are about some sort of timeing…?
I have been taking a “peek under the hood” of some other servers, and some of them are using
“Bluurr’s sexy timer” (or something like that).
If I’m not completely wrong, it has to do with determing how long the client listener’s threads are
going to “sleep”, I take it?
What I want to know here is why these timers are here, and why I can’t simply delete them…

Defineing classes(?):
This may be more of a question for Java than RSPS-related, but here I go:
Also in the server/source’s “server.java”-file, there are some other commands that catches my eyes.
Let me take an example… “GraphicsHandler = new GraphicsHandler();”.
Yet again, if I’m not wrong, it defines (in this case) the “GraphicsHandler.java”-file to “server.java”.
But I am used to define classes in a little bit different way, like this:
“GraphicsHandler = new GraphicsHandler();”.
You then have to call the class by it’s “nickname” when ever you are refering to it.

That’s it.
I do NOT claim to be a professor in english.
I do NOT claim to be a professor in Java.
I do NOT claim to be the most experienced RS/RSPS player/coder among us all…

Looking forward for feedback.

Read full topic
